linkTarget.anchoringText: The analysis showed that none of the analogue reservoirs were filled to spill and this helped to rule out the use of the spill point as a constraining factor for hydrocarbon limit. Figure 1 below is a display of the hydrocarbon column trend in Okoro field. This analysis gives a range of hydrocarbon column thicknesses between 135 – 200 ft. which results in a hydrocarbon contact prediction between 9295 – 9360ftss for the B3.2 reservoir.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Hydrocarbon column trend analysis in Okoro field (arranged in increasing HC column thickness)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Hydrocarbon column trend analysis in Okoro field (arranged in increasing HC column thickness)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Strong continuous high amplitude was observed from the crest of the structure to about 9345ftss for B3.2, as such 9345ftss was adopted as high case hydrocarbon water contact i.e. maximum possible hydrocarbon fill. Furthermore, the clouding pattern of the data points into 2 distinctive groups (shown by purple line in figure 2) is indicative of a 2 fluid system (gas and water).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Acoustic amplitude cross plot showing amplitude shutoff

formatted-caption.caption-text: Acoustic amplitude cross plot showing amplitude shutoff

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Pressure depth analysis to predict likely GWC

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure depth analysis to predict likely GWC

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Conceptual view of Okoro B3.2 reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Conceptual view of Okoro B3.2 reservoir

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Economic analysis for each subsurface realization

formatted-caption.caption-text: Economic analysis for each subsurface realization

linkTarget.anchoringText: A decision tree to chart possible subsurface scenarios and their resulting outcomes for the appraisal well scenario was developed. The likely development scenarios for the various realisations were also evaluated. These are gas only, concurrent oil and gas or sequential oil and gas development options for both the appraisal and no appraisal case as shown in figure 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Decision tree showing subsurface realizations and development options

formatted-caption.caption-text: Decision tree showing subsurface realizations and development options

linkTarget.anchoringText: Economic analysis was run for each scenario using results from dynamic reservoir simulation. The possible combinations in consideration are as shown in the VoI diagram in Figure 8. The expectation value for each node was calculated by summing the product of Net Present Values (NPV) and probability of occurrences.
